To re-adorn and re-illume his heav'n;
Since in the end derision
Shall prove his works, and all his efforts, vain;
For Lucifer alone was that full light,
Which scatter'd radiance o'er the plains of Heav'n.
But these his present fires are shade and smoke,
Base counterfeits of my more potent beams;
I reck not what he means to make his heav'n,
Nor care I what this creature man may be,
Too obstinate and firm
Is my undaunted thought
In proving that I am implacable,
'Gainst heav'n, 'gainst man, the angels, and their God.

DIV3.HEAD: ATTO TERZA. SCENA PRIMA.
DIV3.L: OMIA compagna amata,
O di questa mia vita
Vero cor, cara vita;
Si frettolosa a dunque ali vibrando
Peregrina incessante
Per ritrovar Adamo,
Solinga andavi errando?
Eccolo; che l' imponi? Parla homai
Tanto indugi? deh chiede; o Dio, che fai?

SP.SPEAKER: EVA.
SP.L: O mia scorta, o mio duce
Ch' à rallegrar ch' a solazzar m' induce;

SP.SPEAKER: ADAMO.
SP.L: Del tuo gioir nomar radice, e fonte,
Hor t' agrada, mostrarti amica, intendo
Cosa si vaga, che per maraviglia
Mira, sposa gentile, in quella parte
Di cosi folta, e verdeg giante selva
La dove appunto quelle due si bianche
Un vivo humore, il qual con torto passo
Ch' è forza dir; ferma bel rivo, aspet ta:
Tu pur il segui; ed ei come s 'havesse
Fra mille occulte vie depinte, herbose
Anzi note a lui sol celato fugge:
Che tu t' affligi, perche l'hai smarrito
Alza la chioma acquosa, e par che dica
Segui pur segui, il molle passo mio,
Che se godi di mi, con te scherz' io;
Cosi con dolce inganno alfin ti guida
D'un praticel fiorito; ed egli alhora,
Dice: rimanti; addio, già, già, ti lascio
Forz' è che l' occhio il segua; e la tu miri
Come gran copia d' acqua in cerchio angusto
Accoglie in cupa, e fruttuosa valle
D' allor cinta, e d' ulive,
Di cipressi; d' aranci, e d' alti pini;
Il qual limpido humore, a i rai del sole,
Quind' è che nel bel fondo
Tralucer miri ricca arena d' oro
Candidi cigni a la bel onda intorno;
E sembran gorgheggiando a l' aura dire
Qui fermi il pi chi brama à pien gioire.

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.L: Cosi ben la tua lingua mi scoperse
Ben anco è vaga questa parte ov' hora
Facciam grato soggiorno, e qui fors' anco,
Piu ch' altrove, biancheggia il vago giglio
E s' invermiglia la nascente rosa;

SP.SPEAKER: ADAMO.
SP.L: Hor al fresco de l' ombre,
Al mormorar de l' acque e de gli augelli,

SP.SPEAKER: EVA.
SP.L: O come godo in rimirar non solo,
Questi fior, queste herbette, e quante piante
Tù tù sei quel per cui vezzosi i prati
Piu coloriti i frutti, e i fonti cari.

SP.SPEAKER: ADAMO.
SP.L: Leggiadri fior questi be' campi adorni,
Che vie piu vaghi fiori io non rimiri
Nel bel giardin del tuo leggiadro volto;
Voi da rugiade aeree asperse siete,
Voi lieto fate humil terreno herboso,
Ad un sol fiammeggiar d' acceso sole,
Ma co'l cader del sol voi pur cadrete.
D' Eva mia cara e bella,
Ed al rotar di duo terreni soli,
Nel ciel de la sua fronte

SP.SPEAKER: EVA.
SP.L: L' orrecchio armonizar, dir Eva, io t' amo,
Che sfavilli di puro e santo ardore,
Hor tu ricevi in cambio, ò caro amico,
Questo vermiglio don; ben lo conosci,

SP.SPEAKER: ADAMO.
SP.L: Lasso me, che remiro? ohime, che festi,

SP.SPEAKER: EVA.
SP.L: A far preda del pomo. Hor basti ch' io
D' ali impennarti al ciel l' acquisto feci.

SP.SPEAKER: ADAMO.
SP.L: Ah non sia ver, non sia
Ch' à te per esser grato
Mi mostri al cielo ribellante, ingrato,
Disubidisca al mio Fattore, a Dio.
Non ti fe per terror la guance smorte.

SP.SPEAKER: EVA.
SP.L: Che l' havesse inalzato il gran cultore
Ch' a le luci de l' huomo,
Fertileggiar l' havesse fatto a l' aure?
Ah se cio fosse, ben n' havrebb' ei dato
Che per viver quest' humo si pasca e cibi,
E che conforme il bello, il buono ei creda.

SP.SPEAKER: ADAMO.
SP.L: Che i bei campi del cielo,
Fra tante piante fruttose, è belle
Il piu bello, il piu dolce;
E del gran meritar per dargli il modo;
Che sol nome di forte avien che acquisti,
Chi supera se stesso, e i proprii affetti:
Ben havria di peccar ragion quest huomo,
Ma di tanti e si dolci egli abondando
Non dovrà l' huomo in bando,

SP.SPEAKER: EVA.
SP.L: Ah non sia ver, non sia,
Ch' io ti chiami il mio cor, la vita mia,

SP.SPEAKER: ADAMO.
SP.L: Ch' è tutto mio quel pianto,
Che l' irriga la guancia, e innonda il seno.

SP.SPEAKER: EVA.
SP.L: Io, che cotanto dissi, e fece intentà,
Sovra d' ogni alto Cielo, hor cosi poco

SP.SPEAKER: EVA.
SP.L: Che le lagrime mie, che i miei sospiri,
Ond' hor à venti, à' mari,

SP.SPEAKER: ADAMO.
SP.L: Che far deggià non so; s' io miro il cielo
Per l' osse che mi strugge,
Vago sol d' osservar precettì éterni:
Piango al suo pianto, à' suoi sospir sospiro,
E mi struggo e m' accoro,
S' ubidirla rifiuto: il cor amante
Fa ch' al pomo veloce apra la mano.
Accampano il tuo cor varii desiri,
Qui per l' un tu sospiri,
Per l' altro godi, nè saper t' e' dato
Da la donna o da Dio.

SP.SPEAKER: EVA.
SP.L: Vuol ch' Eva solo in bando,
E pur ohimè hò d' ogni antezza il pomo.

SP.SPEAKER: ADAMO.
SP.L: Pria, che parli la lingua, il cor conceda,
Piu il bel ciel de la fronte
A fugar a irraggiar guancia nembosa;
Da quella massa d' or, che 'l volto inchioma
Bei legami del cor, lampo de gli occhi:
La portin l' aure, e si discopra il viso
De la gloria d' un cor bel paradiso
Sù sù, ne le occhi e ne le labra intanto,
Fa balenar il riso, asciuga il pianto.

SP.SPEAKER: EVA.
SP.L: Corri, corri hoggimai, tocchi la mano,
D' esca beante il fortunato segno.

SP.SPEAKER: ADAMO.
SP.L: Le sirti d' aspro duolo, a lui volgendo
Che tra fior, che tra frondi

SP.SPEAKER: EVA.
SP.L: Che sai dir? lo gustai, nè son già morta
Anzi farsi nel ciel simili à Dio;
A bel trono di raï, trono stellato,
Ne condurran le angeli lieti à volo.

SP.SPEAKER: ADAMO.
SP.L: Per farmi un Dio ha faticato e pianto
Quale me scende al cor acuta spina

SP.SPEAKER: EVA.
SP.L: O conoscenza acerba, o vista nova,
Il tutto s' arma al precipicio humano.

SP.SPEAKER: ADAMO.
SP.P: Ahi cara libertade ove se' gita?

SP.SPEAKER: EVA.
SP.P: O cara libertate, o sier servaggio.

SP.SPEAKER: ADAMO
SP.L: Dove lieto i godea vita felice?
Di morté a le crud armi
Tu pur, ch' eri mia vita?

SP.SPEAKER: EVA.
SP.L: A le soglie cadei del basso inferno.

SP.SPEAKER: ADAMO.
SP.L: Ahi qual dardo divin me sembra in cielo,

SP.SPEAKER: EVA.
SP.L: Lassa me ne sovrasta? Ohime son nuda,

SP.SPEAKER: ADAMO.
SP.P: Nudo son? Chi mi cela? io parto.

DIV3.HEAD: ACT THIRD. SCENE I.
DIV3.L: O MY belov'd companion,
O thou of my existence
The very heart and soul,
Hast thou, with such excess of tender haste,
With ceaseless pilgrimage,
To find again thy Adam
Thus solitary wandered?
Behold him, speak, what are thy gentle orders?
Why dost thou pause? O God, what art thou doing?

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.L: Thou source of all my comfort, all my joy,

SP.SPEAKER: ADAM.
SP.L: Since thou may'st call thy Adam
The source and happy fountain of thy joy,
Eve; if to walk with me
It now may please thee, I will shew thee, love,
A sight thou hast not seen,
A sight so lovely, that in wonder thou
Look thou, my gentle bride, towards that path
Of this so intricate and verdant grove,
Just there, where now, with soft and snowy plumes,
Two social doves have spread their wings for flight;
Just there thou shalt behold (O pleasing wonder)
A living stream, that with a winding course
And tempts you to exclaim, sweet river stay;
You follow, and the stream, as if it had
Thro' many a florid, many a grassy way,
Well known to him, in soft concealment flies;
But when at length he hears
You are afflicted to have lost his sight
He rears his watry locks, and seems to say,
Follow, ah follow still my placid course,
If thou art pleased with me, with thee I sport;
And thus, with sweet deceit, he leads you on
Of a fair flow'ry meadow, then at once,
Says, stop, adieu, for now, yes, now I leave you,
There, as no human foot can follow farther,
The eye alone must follow him, and there,
In little space, you see a mass of water
Collected in a deep and fruitful vale,
With cypress, oranges, and lofty pines;
The limpid water in the sun's bright ray
You see a precious glittering sand of gold,
The snowy swans upon the shining streams
And seem in warbling to the wind to say,
Here let those rt who wish for perfect joy.
To walk with me will please thee.

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.L: So well thy language to my sight has brought
What thou desiredst to shew me,
I see thy flying river as it sports,
And hear it as it murmurs:
And beauteous also is this scene where now
Pleas'd we sojourn; and here, perhaps e'en here
The lilly whitens with the purest lustre,
And the rose reddens with the richest hue;

SP.SPEAKER: ADAM.
SP.L: By the soft music of the rills and birds,
Let us sit down in joy.

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.L: How I rejoice in viewing, not alone,
These flow'rs, these herbs, these high and graceful plants.
Thou, thou art he by whom the meadows seem
The fruit more blooming, and the streams more clear.

SP.SPEAKER: ADAM.
SP.L: With all their flow'ry tribute, cannot equal
Those lovelier flowers that with delight I view
In the fair garden of your beauteous face;
You shine besprinkl'd with aetherial dew,
You give the humble earth to grow with joy
At one bright sparkle of the blazing sun;
But with the falling sun ye also fall:
And by the rays of two terrestrial suns,
In that pure Heav'n her face,
They rise, and not to fall,

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.L: To sooth my ear by speaking of thy love;
That fondly flames with pure and hallow'd ardour;
In sweet exchange accept, my gentle love,
This vermeil tinctur'd gift; you know it well;

SP.SPEAKER: ADAM.
SP.L: Alas! what see I! Ah! what hast thou done?

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.L: It would be long to tell
To make this fruit my prey; let it suffice,
I've gained thee wings to raise thy flight to heav'n.

SP.SPEAKER: ADAM.
SP.L: Ne'er be it true, ah! never,
I prove to Heav'n rebellious and ungrateful,
So disobey my Maker and my God.
With terror's icy paleness blanch thy cheek?

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.L: And think'st thou, if the apple
Were but the fruit of death,
The great Producer would have raised it there,
Think'st thou, that if of error
He would have form'd it flourishing in air?
Ah! were it so, he would indeed have giv'n
That to support his being man must eat,
And trust in what looks fair as just and good.

SP.SPEAKER: ADAM.
SP.L: Who the fair face of heav'n
Amidst so many plants, fruitful and fair,
As a wise keeper of his heav'nly law,
And to afford him scope for high desert;
For he alone may gain the name of brave
Who rules himself, and all his own desires;
Man might, indeed, find some excuse for sin,
But this abounding in so many sweets,

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.L: And is it thus you love me?
Ne'er be it true, ah never,
That I address you as my heart, my life;
Bath'd in my tears and sighing,
I'll hide me from the sun.

SP.SPEAKER: ADAM.
SP.L: O haste to dry thine eyes,
For mine are all these tears
That bathe thy cheek and stream upon thy bosom.

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.L: I that so much have said, so much have done
Above the highest heav'n, and now so little
Can he or trust or love me.

SP.SPEAKER: ADAM.
SP.L: Ah do not grieve, my life;
Too much it wounds my soul

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.L: Is to be witness to my sighs and tears;
Hence to the winds and seas

SP.SPEAKER: ADAM.
SP.L: What can I do? When I look up to heav'n
E'en thro' my bones, oppress me;
Anxious alone to guard the heav'nly precept,
I share her tears and echo back her sighs;
To wound her with refusal: my kind heart
Would teach my op'ning hand to seize the apple,
Various desires besiege thy trembling heart;
One prompts thee now to sigh,
Another to rejoice, nor canst thou know

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.L: E'en while I hold the fruit of exaltation.

SP.SPEAKER: ADAM.
SP.L: Are all your looks, my love;
And my heart grants before your tongue can speak:
Eyes that to me are suns,
The heav'n of that sweet face,
To scatter radiance o'er that cloudy cheek:
Lift up, O lift thy brow
From that soft mass of gold that curls around it,
Chains to my heart, and lightning to my eyes,
Sport in the air, and all thy face disclose
That paradise that speaks a heart divine.
Dry, dry thy streaming eyes, and on thy lips
Let tender smiles like harmless light'ning play.

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.L: Hasten, now hasten to extend thy hand
To press this banquet of beatitude.

SP.SPEAKER: ADAM.
SP.L: The whirlpool of affliction, turn'd to him
His dearest guide, his radiant polar star:
Ingenious plunderer, thou hid'st from me.

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.L: What say'st thou? I have tasted, and yet live.
And make us equal to our God in heav'n;
And when we have enjoyed it,
Then to a radiant throne, a throne of stars,
Exulting angels will direct our flight.

SP.SPEAKER: ADAM.
SP.L: Give me the fruit that charms thee,
And let me yield to her,
Who, to make me a god, has toiled and wept.
How sharp a thorn is piercing in my heart
In a vast flood of tears.

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.L: All is prepared for human misery.

SP.SPEAKER: ADAM.
SP.P: O precious liberty, where art thou fled?

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.P: O precious liberty! O dire enthralment!

SP.SPEAKER: ADAM.
SP.L: Is this the fruit so sweet,
The source of so much bitter?
Say, why would'st thou betray me?
Ah why of heav'n deprive me?
Where cheerful I enjoy a blissful life?
Why make me thus a slave
To the fierce arms of death,
Thou whom I deemed my life?

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.L: I have been blind to good,
To the high gates of heav'n,
I fall presumptuous to the depths of hell.

SP.SPEAKER: ADAM.
SP.L: Alas, what dart divine appears in heav'n,

SP.SPEAKER: EVE.
SP.L: Wretch that I am, hangs o'er me? Am I naked,

SP.SPEAKER: ADAM.
SP.P: Am I too naked? Shelter, hence.

DIV2.HEAD: ANALYSIS OF THE DRAMA, ENTITLED, La Scena Tragica d' ADAMO ed EVA; DA TROILO LANCETTA BENACENSE.

DIV3.HEAD: ACT THE FIRST.
DIV3.P: SCENE 1. GOD COMMEMORATES his creation of the heavens, the earth, and the water—determines to make man—gives him vital spirit, and admonishes him to revere his Maker, and live innocent.
SCENE 2. RAPHAEL, MICHAEL, GABRIEL, and ANGELS. Raphael praises the works of God—the other angels follow his example, particularly in regard to man.
SCENE 3. GOD and ADAM. God gives paradise to Adam to hold as a fief—forbids him to touch the apple—Adam promises obedience.
SCENE 4. ADAM. Acknowledges the beneficence of God, and retires to repose in the shade.

DIV3.HEAD: ACT THE SECOND.
DIV3.P: SCENE 1. GOD and ADAM. GOD resolves to form a companion for Adam, and does so while Adam is sleeping—he then awakes Adam, and pre∣senting to him his new associate, blesses them both; then leaves them, recommending obedience to his commands.

SCENE 2. ADAM and EVE. Adam receives Eve as his wife—praises her, and entreats her to join with him in revering and obeying God—she promises submission to his will, and intreats his instruction— he tells her the prohibition, and enlarges on the beauties of Paradise—on his speaking of flocks, she desires to see them, and he departs to shew her the various animals.

SCENE 3. LUCIFER, BELIAL, SATAN. Lucifer laments his expulsion from heaven, and meditates revenge against man—the other demons relate the cause of
their expulsion, and stimulate Lucifer to the revenge he meditates—he resolves to employ the Serpent.

SCENE 4. The SERPENT, EVE, LUCIFER. The Serpent questions Eve—derides her fear and her obe∣dience—tempts her to taste the apple—she expresses her eagerness to do so—the Serpent exults in the prospect of her perdition—Lucifer (who seems to remain as a separate person from the Serpent) expresses also his exultation, and steps aside to listen to a dialogue between Adam and Eve.

SCENE 5. EVE, ADAM. Eve declares her resolution to taste the apple, and present it to her husband—she tastes it, and expresses unusual hope and animation—she says the Serpent has not deceived her— she feels no sig of death, and presents the fruit to her husband—he reproves her—she persists in pressing him to eat—he complies—declares the fruit sweet, but begins to tremble at his own nakedness—he repents, and expresses his remorse and terror—Eve proposes to form a covering of leaves—they retire to hide themselves in foliage.

DIV3.HEAD: ACT THE THIRD.
DIV3.P: SCENE 1. LUCIFER, BELIAL, SATAN. LUCIFER exults in his success, and the other demons ap∣plaud him.
SCENE 2. RAPHAEL, MICHAEL, GABRIEL. These good spirits lament the fall, and retire with awe on the appearance of God.

SCENE 3. GOD, EVE, ADAM. God calls on Adam—he appears and laments his nakedness —God interrogates him concerning the tree—he confesses his offence, and accuses Eve—she blames the Serpent—God pro∣nounces his malediction, and sends them from his presence.

SCENE 4. RAPHAEL, EVE, and ADAM. Raphael bids them depart from Paradise—Adam laments his destiny—Raphael persists in driving them rather harshly from the garden—Adam begs that his innocent children may
not suffer for the fault of their mother—Raphael replies, that not only his children, but all his race, must suffer, and continues to drive them from the garden—Adam obeys—Eve laments, but soon comforts Adam—he at length departs, animating himself with the idea, that to an intrepid heart every region is a home.
SCENE 5 A CHERUB, Moralizing on the creation and fall of Adam, conclude the third and last act.
